articles.headline: States Want More in Pension Contributions
articles.snippet: Gaping pension shortfalls are forcing states to get more money from workers, some of whom have already accepted wage freezes and higher health insurance contributions.
articles.abstract: Gaping pension shortfalls are forcing states to get more money from workers, some of whom have already accepted wage freezes and higher health insurance contributions.
articles.lead_paragraph: First came the pay freezes and unpaid furloughs. Then came the higher contributions for health insurance. Now, in the most definitive sign yet that the era of generous compensation for public-sector employees is ending, workers in more than half the states face the prospect of paying more of their salary toward their pensions.

articles.headline: A Laptop, Its Head in the Cloud
articles.snippet: Google’s Chromebook concept for laptops is built on the assumption that you can get online almost anywhere.
articles.abstract: Google’s Chromebook concept for laptops is built on the assumption that you can get online almost anywhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: You can say all kinds of nice things about Google’s Chromebook laptop concept. You can say it’s ahead of its time. Or that it’s thinking way, way outside the box. Or that, as failures go, at least this one swung for the fences.

articles.headline: Still Writing, Regulators Delay Rules
articles.snippet: Regulators overseeing financial reform are delaying many changes in the market for derivatives because they are running behind schedule in writing their new rules.
articles.abstract: Regulators overseeing financial reform are delaying many changes in the market for derivatives because they are running behind schedule in writing their new rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: Regulators overseeing financial reform are delaying many of the planned changes in the immense market for complex securities known as derivatives because they are running drastically behind schedule in writing their new rules.

articles.headline: Nuclear Plant, Left for Dead, Shows a Pulse
articles.snippet: The Tennessee Valley Authority says a half-built nuclear plant shelved 23 years ago may be its best bet for new energy.
articles.abstract: The Tennessee Valley Authority says a half-built nuclear plant shelved 23 years ago may be its best bet for new energy.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD, Ala. — Spider webs line the 50-story cooling towers, parts have been amputated for the scrap value of their nickel or copper, and the control room still has analog dials at Bellefonte 1, a half-built nuclear plant here that was shelved 23 years ago.

articles.headline: Where Others Have Gone Without Success, J.C. Penney Goes Again
articles.snippet: With a new chief executive, J. C. Penney is setting out to rethink the shopping experience.
articles.abstract: With a new chief executive, J. C. Penney is setting out to rethink the shopping experience.
articles.lead_paragraph: Trying to redefine itself, Sears Holdings introduced a flurry of concepts when its new chairman, Edward S. Lampert, took over.

articles.headline: Ex-Spy Alleges Bush White House Sought to Discredit Critic
articles.snippet: Intelligence officials dispute the account of a former C.I.A. official who says he was pressed to find personal information to discredit a critic of the Iraq war.
articles.abstract: Intelligence officials dispute the account of a former C.I.A. official who says he was pressed to find personal information to discredit a critic of the Iraq war.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A former senior C.I.A. official says that officials in the Bush White House sought damaging personal information on a prominent American critic of the Iraq war in order to discredit him.

articles.headline: Pakistan’s Chief of Army Fights to Keep His Job
articles.snippet: Pakistan’s army chief, the most powerful man in the country, is facing seething anger from top generals and junior officers since the American raid that killed Osama bin Laden.
articles.abstract: Pakistan’s army chief, the most powerful man in the country, is facing seething anger from top generals and junior officers since the American raid that killed Osama bin Laden.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s army chief, the most powerful man in the country, is fighting to save his position in the face of seething anger from top generals and junior officers since the American raid that killed Osama bin Laden, according to Pakistani officials and people who have met the chief in recent weeks.

articles.headline: American Retailers Try Again in Europe
articles.snippet: The expansion of chains like Abercrombie and Gap to Europe is based on a major shift in how young Europeans think about American fashion.
articles.abstract: The expansion of chains like Abercrombie and Gap to Europe is based on a major shift in how young Europeans think about American fashion.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — On a recent Sunday afternoon, the Champs-Élysées was packed with people enjoying this city’s most famous boulevard — window shopping, sipping wine at sidewalk cafes and strolling toward the river with ice cream cones.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Stores Demand Mannequins With Personality (Heads Optional)
articles.snippet: The generic white, hairless, skinny mannequin is being pushed aside by provocative alternatives that entice shoppers with muscles, unusual poses, famous faces and lifelike bodies.
articles.abstract: The generic white, hairless, skinny mannequin is being pushed aside by provocative alternatives that entice shoppers with muscles, unusual poses, famous faces and lifelike bodies.
articles.lead_paragraph: “One size fits all” no longer applies to mannequins.

articles.headline: Qaeda Selection of Its Chief Is Said to Reflect Its Flaws
articles.snippet: American officials said that the deep flaws of Ayman al-Zawahri may weaken the terrorist network.
articles.abstract: American officials said that the deep flaws of Ayman al-Zawahri may weaken the terrorist network.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American counterterrorism officials all but welcomed the announcement on Thursday that Ayman al-Zawahri would succeed Osama bin Laden as leader of Al Qaeda, arguing that his deep flaws are likely to weaken the core of the terrorist network.

articles.headline: Greek Turmoil Raises Fears of Instability Around Europe
articles.snippet: A rising tide of voter anger against bank bailouts, budget cuts and austerity measures is threatening to undermine efforts to rescue the financial system.
articles.abstract: A rising tide of voter anger against bank bailouts, budget cuts and austerity measures is threatening to undermine efforts to rescue the financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The instability rocking Greece this week is the latest manifestation of a troubling new phase in the global financial crisis: political turmoil is sweeping through Europe, toppling governments and threatening to undermine efforts to rescue the financial system and, ultimately, the euro zone itself.

articles.headline: Top Spanish Banker Faces Inquiry on Tax Charges
articles.snippet: Emilio Botín, the chairman of Banco Santander, and 11 of his relatives have become the subject of a huge investigation into tax evasion.
articles.abstract: Emilio Botín, the chairman of Banco Santander, and 11 of his relatives have become the subject of a huge investigation into tax evasion.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID — Spain’s already fragile banking sector was shocked Thursday by the news that Emilio Botín, the country’s most influential banker and chairman of Banco Santander, and 11 of his relatives were the subjects of an investigation into tax evasion stretching back to accounts that ostensibly were opened during the dark days of the Spanish Civil War.
